definitions.definition: From a higher position to a lower one; downwards .
examples: The cat jumped down from the table.

definitions.definition: To or towards what is considered the bottom of something, irrespective of whether this is presently physically lower.
examples: Go down to the bottom of the page.
As I lay on my back, a pain shot down from my neck to my waist.

definitions.definition: At a lower or further place or position along a set path.
examples: His place is farther down the road.
The company was well down the path to bankruptcy.

definitions.definition: To the south (as south is at the bottom of typical maps).
examples: I went down to Miami for a conference.

definitions.definition: Away from the city (regardless of direction).
examples: He went down to Cavan.
down on the farm
down to the country

definitions.definition: At or towards any place that is visualised as 'down' by virtue of local features or local convention, or arbitrarily, irrespective of direction or elevation change.
examples: She lives down by the park.

definitions.definition: Forward, straight ahead.
examples: At the first intersection turn left and walk down , then turn right.

definitions.definition: In the direction leading away from the principal terminus, away from milepost zero.
Away from Oxford or Cambridge .
examples: He's gone back down to Newcastle for Christmas.

definitions.definition: To a subordinate or less prestigious position or rank.
examples: Smith was sent down to the minors to work on his batting.
After the incident, Kelly went down to Second Lieutenant.

definitions.definition: Towards the opponent's side (in ball-sports).
So as to lessen quantity, level or intensity.
examples: You need to tone down the rhetoric.
Please turn the music down !

definitions.definition: So as to reduce size, weight or volume.
examples: Trim the stick down to a length of about twelve inches.
Thanks to my strict diet, I've slimmed down to eleven stone.
Boil the mixture down to a syrupy consistency.

definitions.definition: From less to greater detail.
examples: This spreadsheet lets you drill down to daily or even hourly sales figures.

definitions.definition: From a remoter or higher antiquity.
examples: These traditions have been handed down over generations.

definitions.definition: Into a state of non- operation .
examples: The computer has been shut down .
They closed the shop down .

definitions.definition: So as to secure or compress something to the floor, ground, or other (usually horizontal) surface.
examples: We need to nail down this carpet so people don't keep tripping over it.

definitions.definition: On paper (or in a durable record ).
examples: You need to write down what happened while it's still fresh in your mind.

definitions.definition: So as to be cowed into silence .
examples: The speaker was heckled and shouted down .
The comedy club's audience was known for hooting down timid performers.

definitions.definition: As a down payment .
examples: We put £100 down on a new sofa.
You can have it, no money down .

definitions.definition: In a downwards direction; vertically.
examples: I'm stuck on 11 down .
labels: in relation to a numbered clued word
definitions.label_groups: crosswords, in relation to a numbered clued word

definitions.definition: Used with verbs to indicate that the action of the verb was carried to some state of completion, permanence, or success rather than being of indefinite duration.
examples: He closed operations. / He closed down operations.
He chased answers. / He chased down answers.

definitions.definition: Get down .
examples: Down , boy! ( such as to direct a dog to stand on four legs from two, or to sit from standing on four legs. )

main_definition: ( comparable ) From a higher position to a lower one; downwards .
